Second, describing the transformation of the body, in four parts:
First, asking and answering about whether the body is permanent or impermanent.
The Buddha told the great king:
Your present body, I now ask you again, is this physical body the same as vajra, permanently abiding and not decaying, or does it transform and perish?
World-Honored One!
This body of mine will eventually transform and perish.
The Buddha raised this question to reveal that within birth and cessation there is non-birth and non-cessation, just as when the head itself moves, the seeing has no movement.
Second, asking and answering about knowing cessation without having ceased.
The Buddha said:
Great King!
You have never ceased, how do you know cessation?
World-Honored One!

Although this impermanent and changing body of mine has never ceased, I observe that moment by moment it is in transition, with nothing remaining new. Like fire becoming ash, gradually dissipating and vanishing, vanishing without rest. I am certain that this body will eventually cease.
The previous thought ceases and the subsequent thought arises, changing moment by moment, like fire burning fuel, inevitably returning to extinction.
The Abhidharma-koÅ›a says, Because all conditioned dharmas have a moment of exhaustion.
Third, asking and answering about the appearance of old and young.
The Buddha said:
So it is.
Great King!
Now that you have reached old age, how does your appearance compare to when you were a young boy?
The king recounted the truth of impermanence, moment by moment changing, and thus affirmed it as such.
He wanted to further describe the characteristics of change, using the comparison of old and young as a question.
Fifteen years old is a youth, not yet wearing a cap and gown.
Longevity is years.
World-Honored One!

When I was a child, my skin was smooth and lustrous. When I reached adulthood, my blood and qi were full. Now, my declining years are pressing upon me with decrepitude. When first born, it is called a child. When first able to walk, it is called a youth.

Growing up refers to the time when one becomes an adult. This is from the age of twenty onwards until one is strong and healthy, hence it says blood and qi are full.
Declining years refers to the present age of sixty-two. The years are declining and close to seventy, hence it says close to old age and senility.
Old and young are different, how is it that the World-Honored One sees them as similar?

Great King!

Previously describing the change in appearance, now asking about the change in years, because of the change in years it causes the change in appearance.

Third, demonstrating the indestructibility of nature, in three parts:
First, the Buddha asks about indestructibility, and the king answers that he does not know.
The Buddha said to the great king:

The coarse characteristics of birth and death are as previously understood, and the nature of non-birth and non-death is also in your body. Do you know it or not?
King Prasenajit raised external doubts, wishing for the World-Honored One to clarify, and now, being questioned by the Buddha, he answered that he does not know.

Below this, it is about the king's seeing the river unchanged from childhood to adulthood to clarify the nature of seeing, intending to show that only within birth and death is there non-birth and non-death. Second, extensive discussion through questioning and refutation, in three parts:
First, initial question and answer regarding seeing the river.

The words without difference are very good to contemplate. At first glance, they seem superficial, but upon further thought, they have meaning.

Second, directly confronting Ä€nanda and refuting his view of eternalism, in two parts:

According to this, the seeing in the river of seeing is no different from my seeing and hearing. To the king, it is said to be non-extinguishing and non-arising, but to me, it is said to be losing the true nature.
Who is closer to the king and who is more distant from me? If they are different paths, how can they be distinguished?

However, the meaning of this question has been around for a long time. First, asking.
At that time, the TathÄgata hung down his golden-colored arm, pointed with his wheel-marked hand, and said to Ä€nanda:

Pointing down means pointing below.

This meaning wants to clarify that seeing the hand is not the same, some is correct and some is inverted, using this to illustrate that its seeing also has correct and inverted.

The Buddha told Ä€nanda:

Fourth, the explanation.
Ä€nanda said:

Raising the hand upside down and considering it to be right is considered upside down because it is not in accordance with the body.
Ä€nanda does not distinguish the true from the false, and grasps the false, losing the true. Therefore, the TathÄgata reproaches him for acting in an upside-down manner.

Since he understands that the false originally has no substance, he should know that the true is naturally tranquil. He then allows him to face the moving vision and observe the nature of the river. This is precisely the true nature, there is no separate true nature.

However, Ä€nanda still does not understand. He thinks that there is a true nature outside of the false. He then cannot accept that he is a person who acts in an upside-down manner, and that the king is the nature that is unborn.

Since Ä€nanda has already presented his argument, the TathÄgata uses the matter to examine him. He is unable to distinguish the inverted and non-inverted realms, and it is difficult for him to escape the state of upside-down thinking.

Second, raising the arm to show the comparison of the upside-down vision.
The Buddha then raised his arm and said to Ä€nanda:

Since it is said that raising the arm is correct, the Buddha raised his arm and then accused him, this is the very inversion.
The original position of the arm was hanging down, but now it is raised against the norm, therefore it is said that the head and tail are switched.

People do not rely on the original nature to take the correct as correct, but give rise to different views to take the inverted as correct, therefore it is said that they look at it with a hundred times more attention.

Then you will know that your body, compared with the TathÄgata's pure Dharma body, is manifested as being of the same kind. The TathÄgata's body is called the one with right and universal knowledge, while your bodies are called those with inverted natures.

If this is used to examine it, then you will know that your body, compared with the TathÄgata's body, is manifested as being of the same kind. The Buddha's body is correct, while your body should be inverted.
Alternatively, if the Buddha's seen hand is used to manifest the Buddha's body, it is clear that the Buddha's body is called the one with right and universal knowledge.
If the seen hand of you is used to compare with your body, it is clear that your body is called the one with inverted natures.
Are you not acting in a contrary manner?
One of perfect and universal knowledge is called correct because free from contrariness, and is called universal knowledge because exhausting the Dharma realm.
Ordinary beings and the two vehicles do not have this title because they are all contrary.
Second, questioning the location of contrariness, in two parts:

According to your careful observation of your body and the Buddha's body, as to what is contrary, in what place is the name called contrary?
According to means still following.
Allow you to carefully examine and contemplate in your mind, if the Buddha is contrary, in what place of the Buddha's body is it contrary?

Second, describing their ignorance.
At that time, Ä€nanda and the great assembly stared blankly at the Buddha, their eyes unblinking, not knowing where the inversion of body and mind was.
Staring means to look straight ahead.

Hearing the questioning of the inverted place, they were dazed and did not understand. Since they could not utter a single word, they only knew to look straight at the Buddha.
Third, extensively demonstrating the characteristics of inversion, in two parts:
First, arousing compassion and addressing them, narrating what he has always taught.
The Buddha gave rise to compassion and pitied Ä€nanda and the great assembly, emitting a voice like the ocean tide to universally proclaim to those in the assembly:
All good men!
I always say that form, mind, all conditions, and what the mind employs, all conditioned dharmas are only manifested by the mind.
The heavenly drum has no thought, yet it sounds in response to people.

This illustrates the compassionate skillful means of the TathÄgata, which responds to the capacities of beings and preaches the Dharma without waiting to be requested.
Form refers to the eleven types of form.
Mind refers to the eight consciousnesses and their mental factors.
All conditions generally refer to form and mind, or specifically to the dharmas not directly associated with mind.
Mental factors refer to the fifty-one mental factors.
All objects of cognition refer to the six unconditioned dharmas.

These five categories of one hundred dharmas encompass all dharmas without exception. They are all manifestations of the true mind, like images appearing in a mirror, inseparable from the mirror, with no separate substance that can be found.
Question:
The first five unconditioned dharmas have both names and substances that are false, so they can be said to be like shadows without substance, like the preceding dharmas.
The true suchness unconditioned dharma has a false name but a real substance, as it is the nature of all dharmas. Why is it said to be without substance, like a reflected image?
Answer:
The suchness taught in this school is still established in contrast to delusion. Since it is due to a contrast, it becomes a deluded dharma.
As the sutra says, Words and falsehoods reveal all that is true, but falsehood and truth are both false.
It also says, The unconditioned has no arising or ceasing, and is not real like a flower in the sky.
The Perfect Enlightenment Sutra says, The perfect enlightenment gives rise to all pure suchness, bodhi, nirvana, and so forth.
Therefore, the dharmas of the five positions are only manifested by the mind, and are all the same as reflections.
Second, revealing the true and showing the false to rebuke inverted emotions, in two:
First, discerning and explaining the deluded emotions based on dharmas, in five:
First, pointing out.
Your body and mind are all things manifested by the wondrous and bright true essence and wondrous mind.
The mind manifests the body and mind, like a mirror manifesting objects. Objects are not the mirror, because the substance of objects is empty;
The mirror is not the object, because the substance of the mirror is real.
Since emptiness and reality are distinguished, by this, inverted emotions can be recognized.
Second, reprimanding the loss.
How is it that you have lost your original wondrous, perfect, bright mind, and the wondrous, bright, perfect nature, and take the deluded within enlightenment to be real?

Mind is the nature, the essence pervades everywhere, thus it is perfect, without obscurity, thus it is bright, endowed with all dharmas, thus it is precious, it has always been so, not just now, thus it is called original.
Words fail to describe it, the mind cannot reach it, thus it is called wondrous.
It is praised again and again, thus it is repeated.
Enlightenment is precisely the perfect, bright nature.
Delusion is precisely the deluded mind and body.
Where there is delusion, there is enlightenment, like an image in a mirror, the false and real can be distinguished.

Now, abandoning the original nature which is like a mirror, grasping the deluded mind and body which are like an image, not distinguishing the false and real, this is a great loss, thus it is said to take the deluded within enlightenment to be real.
Previously it was said, Where is the name of delusion? Now it precisely points to this place of delusion.
Third, describing delusion.

The obscurity and confusion becomes empty space, and in the obscurity and darkness, form is solidified from the confusion. Form mixed with deluded thoughts, the characteristics of thoughts form the body. Internally, the conditions gather and sway, externally rushing and escaping.
The essence of ignorance is dark, therefore it is called obscurity and confusion.
Internally there is ignorance, externally it manifests as the appearance of space, therefore it is called empty space.
This is the initial kalpa-pollution.
The text below says, Delusion gives rise to empty space.

It also says, You see empty space pervading the realms in the ten directions. Space and vision are not distinguished. Space has no substance, and vision has no awareness. They are woven together in delusion, forming the first layer, which is called the kalpa-pollution.
Among the three subtle [aspects], the two aspects of karmic activity and transformation are also called the same and different, and also called movement and stillness.
Because of the mutual dependence of this movement and stillness, in the obscurity of these two aspects, form and color are solidified, which are the faculties, body, and the external environment.

When form and color manifest, thoughts dwell within them. The combination of form and thoughts gives rise to the sense faculties and body. The still and concentrated aspect of thoughts becomes the external environment. This is the third manifestation.

Because there are objective conditions, coarse consciousness is drawn up, discriminating thought after thought, continuing without interruption. Therefore, it says gathering conditions internally, stirring. These are the first two coarsenesses.

Due to the continuous conditioning of thought, it eventually becomes differentiated, grasping the characteristics of the six sense objects and flowing without rest. Therefore, it says pursuing the external and running wild. This is the latter two coarsenesses of the differentiated consciousness.
From subtle to obvious, the three subtle and four coarse [aspects] constitute the path of afflictions, ending here.
Fourth, revealing attachment.
The appearance of confusion and agitation is taken as the nature of mind. Once deluded as mind, one is definitely confused within the physical body.

Worldly people do not know that this is originally ignorance, which becomes increasingly coarse and agitated. They take this confused and deluded state of agitation to be the true nature of the mind. Once they are deluded and attached to it, they never change their view, saying that their mind is within their physical body. They then give rise to the distinction between sentient and insentient beings, the difference between having Buddha-nature and not having Buddha-nature. They take the deluded mind to be the Buddha-mind. How contemptible their views are!
Fifth, concluding the delusion.
Not knowing that outside the physical body, up to and including mountains, rivers, space, and the great earth, all are things within the wondrous and bright true mind.
The sense faculties, body, and seeds belong to the internal, which are grasped and clung to;
Mountains, rivers, and the great earth belong to the external, which are merely grasped and not clung to. These three realms are all the appearance portion of the store consciousness.
Moreover, this empty realm arises from deluded ignorance, because it is transformed by consciousness;

The transforming consciousness is entirely ignorance, which arises from delusion and confusion about the truth, and also has no self-nature. The transformer and the transformed are all reflected images manifested by the mirror-like mind.
Therefore, the previous text says, Your body and your mind are all things manifested in the true mind.
Not knowing this principle, one instead grasps one's own mind as being within the physical body. Therefore, this concludes by pointing this out.
